title: Kenya: There's No Infrastructure for E-Procurement in Counties, Governors Say
text:
Kenya: Homophobic Mobs Attack LGBT People in Kenya With Impunity - Report By Fatma Mzee 
The Council of Governors has threatened to take the government to court if it continues pushing county governments to use e-procurement and the Integrated Financial Management Information Systems (Ifmis) systems. 
Speaking during a fundraising for small-scale businesswomen held in Garsen, Tana River County, governors Peter Munya (Meru and CoG chairman), Isaac Ruto (Bomet), Ukur Yatani (Marsabit) and Hussein Dado (Tana River) argued that there is no infrastructure to allow such systems to be used countrywide. 
Mr Munya said most counties were left behind during the earlier governments adding that there was no preparedness and readiness to start using the systems when the government enforced them. 
"We will have no choice but to move to court next week if the government continues insisting that we use e-procurement and Ifmis systems because there is nowhere in the Constitution that it is stated we should use it," said Mr Munya. 
Mr Dado called upon the government to suspend the order until proper infrastructure is established adding that its use will lock out small scale businessmen in rural areas. 
"We welcome the use of technology in our operations but this is going to lock out small scale contractors residing in remote areas where network is a nightmare," said Mr Dado. 
He added that the systems have caused delays in service delivery which in turn has affected ongoing projects adding that contractors have not been able to access their funds in time. Kenya
